webTitle: BAE and Rolls-Royce lifted by positive aerospace outlook

fields.standfirst: Citigroup upbeat on civil aerospace sector but more cautious on defence prospects
fields.body:
BAE Systems and Rolls-Royce are among the major risers after positive comments from Citigroup.

In a hefty note on the aerospace and defence sectors, Citi analysts Devang Doshi and Natalia Mamaeva said they were upbeat on civil aerospace but cautious on defence:

Our positive outlook on civil aerospace is driven by ramp-up in production of new aircraft and rising production of legacy aircraft. Record backlogs, better-than-expected aircraft orders and robust air traffic trends remain supportive of an ongoing delivery cycle upturn. We expect civil aftermarket to continue recovering as air traffic remains resilient and de-stocking trends end.
[But] we expect defence budgets in the US and Europe to stay roughly flat over the coming years. The recent US debt ceiling deal has removed some immediate risks overhanging US defence, although these are likely to re- appear early next year. Given tough budgetary conditions in the US and Europe, large export contracts are likely to become important catalysts for Defence share price performance, in our view.

On BAE, up 12.1p to 457p, they kept their neutral rating but raised their target price from 350p to 460p along with their 2014 and 2015 forecasts. They said:

While we like BAE's robust Saudi growth prospects, its large export pipeline and its exposure to both the F-35 and the Eurofighter combat jets, we remain concerned over US defence budgets and its potential impact on BAE. The impact of US sequestration has been relatively limited so far, although the ongoing budget battles suggest more risks for the second half of 2013 and 2014, in our view. The UK defence budgets also face the risk of further cuts as was highlighted in the recent 2013 Spending Review.
While our 2013 forecasts are broadly unchanged, we have raised our 2014-2015 forecasts by 5%-8% mainly to reflect resumption of Saudi Typhoon deliveries and the five-year £1.8bn follow-on Saudi Typhoon support contract awarded in June. We raise our target price to reflect our updated forecasts, a more positive outlook on medium-term sales prospects (which explains about half the increase in target price) and changes in our weighted average cost of capital (which accounts for the remaining increase).

On Rolls, up 21p to £11.13, Citi said:

We maintain our buy rating on Rolls-Royce on account of strong earnings per share growth prospects led by a combination of 7%-8% organic top-line growth, significant margin upside and de-leveraging. Despite 26% share price performance year to date, we believe Rolls-Royce's PE valuation still remains attractive in the context of strong earnings momentum, best-in-class return on capital employed and a net cash balance sheet.
We raise our 2013 earnings per share estimate by 3% driven by higher EBIT forecast at civil aerospace, offset by lower EBIT in the marine and energy segments. Our revised 2014-2015 earnings per share forecasts are around 1% higher than previously and remain 5%-10% above consensus estimates. We raise our target price from 1200p to 1280p driven by a combination of modest earnings upgrades, updated net cash and pension deficit assumptions and an updated weighted average cost of capital of 9.3% versus 9.4% before (reflecting updated market inputs).

webTitle: Tesco food waste: what's inside your fridge? Share your pictures

fields.standfirst: As Tesco vows to cut its waste mountain we'd like to find out what food you will end up throwing away. Share pictures of what's in your your fridge via GuardianWitness
fields.body:
Tesco has disclosed food waste figures for the first time and has revealed that 68% of salad sold in bags is thrown out – 35% of it in the home. The retailer also found out nearly half of its bread is being wasted and 40% of its apples. As a result of these findings, the supermarket chain is going to introduce new measures to help reduce the amount that is thrown away.

It's very easy to forget about food in the fridge, so we'd like to find out what's inside your fridge, what you will definitely eat and what may be thrown away. It's only fair of course, if we're asking to see yours, that we confess just how much food we waste, and some Guardian writers have done just that.

You can share your photos by clicking on the blue 'Contribute' button or downloading the free GuardianWitness app for smartphones. Please use the description box in the photo tab to let us know what items may end up in the bin.

We will select the best content and feature it on the Guardian site alongside our wider coverage.

webTitle: G4S jumps on report of £1bn sale but RBS drops on split reports

fields.standfirst: Private equity said to be interested in bid for outsourcing group's cash solutions business
fields.body:
With markets in relatively buoyant mood now the US debt crisis has been resolved - temporarily at least - outsourcing group G4S is leading the way.

Weekend reports that private equity group Charterhouse Capital could be interested in buying the company's cash solutions business for £1bn have sent its shares soaring 4%, up 9.7p to 251.7p. The division transports cash in its high tech security vehicles and manages ATMs.

Meanwhile, among the mid-caps, defence group Qinetiq has jumped 5.7p to 199.6p following talk it had put its US business up for sale, which could leave the rest of the company vulnerable to a bid. William Shirley at Liberum Capital issued a hold note, saying:

A £256m goodwill impairment precipitated a strategic review for Qinetiq's US Services business at the full year results in May. Yesterday, The Sunday Times reported that the business is to be put up for sale and mooted a potential valuation of £300m-£400m. We believe a disposal is indeed likely but see the suggested valuation as full. A £200m plus valuation would be earnings enhancing assuming all proceeds were used to buy back shares.
There is plenty of food for the bears: multiple headwinds, a problematic US business and a full valuation. However, there is the tantalising prospect of increased shareholder returns once the US strategic review is complete and always the potential for a large order. We expect a weak first half (earnings per share down 35% year on year) to be reported on 21 November.

Overall the FTSE 100 is up 11.30 points at 6633.88, ahead of Tuesday's US non-farm payroll numbers, delayed because of the US government shutdown. With uncertainty over the effect of the closure on the country's economy, most observers believe the US Federal Reserve will be reluctant to begin easing its $85bn a month bond buying programme. Rebecca O'Keeffe at Interactive Investor said:

With the S&P at record highs, the big question for investors is whether markets can go much higher from here. Significant anticipated good news appears to already be factored into current market levels - including the expectation that tapering won't start until December at the earliest, and possibly not until the debt ceiling issue is resolved in February. With better Chinese growth, relatively good corporate earnings and stability in Europe also seemingly priced in, will markets be able to continue their sustained rise, or are investors set for disappointment?
Non-farm payrolls data is usually the most important indicator of the month, but September's US employment report, released tomorrow, is unlikely to provide a catalyst for markets. Instead, investors will be waiting for the October number to provide the full effect of the recent shutdown.

Among the fallers Royal Bank of Scotland is down 19.8p at 352.9p amid growing talk the government will split it into a good and bad bank. Options reportedly under consideration are setting up an independently run bad bank within RBS, separating toxic assets out into a bad bank or establishing a taxpayer backed bad bank into which RBS's toxic assets would be placed.

Analysts are split on the prospects for RBS, with Investec on Friday repeating its sell recommendation. But Shore Capital is more positive, with a buy note just issued. Analyst Gary Greenwood said:

Despite this news, we continue to believe that any good bank/bad bank split will not prove onerous for minority shareholders. Specifically, we note that any good bank/bad bank split would need to meet three objectives, with the third point being key, in our view: maximise the bank's ability to support the British economy; get best value for the taxpayer; and facilitate a return of the bank to private ownership.
We remain relatively sanguine on the subject and re-iterate our positive stance on the shares.

Banks were also under pressure after JP Morgan reportedly made a tentative $13bn settlement relating to bad mortgage loans sold before the 2008 crisis, with other banks also exposed in this area.

Marks & Spencer has lost 8p to 487.1p following news of another top level departure as the retailer struggles to improve its general merchandise sales. Gillian Ridley Whittle, development and buying director for womenswear, told M&S she plans to leave to join Australian department store group Target.

Royal Mail continues its relentless rise, with weekend reports suggesting a number of investment banks had valued it at around £5bn rather than the flotation price of £3.3bn. The shares are at 519p, up 16.5p, after reaching a new high of 532.5p.

webTitle: Merlin Entertainments to float on London Stock Exchange

fields.bodyText: The company behind Madame Tussauds and Legoland is planning to sell shares to the public in a £3bn offer that is a further sign of a buoyant stock market that has sent Royal Mail's stock price soaring. Nick Varney, the chief executive of Merlin Entertainments, which also owns Alton Towers and the London Eye, said the recent revival in initial public offerings had helped the company make its decision to float. "Stock markets on both sides of the Atlantic have been looking healthy … the reception people have given to good-quality IPOs is encouraging." Private equity-owned Merlin was on the brink of a stock market listing in 2010, but pulled out because of market volatility. Merlin's announcement came as renewable energy company Infinis, which is owned by Guy Hands' Terra Firma private equity group, said it was seeking to sell 30% of its shares on the stock market next month. The spate of listings shows how equity markets have come roaring back to life since IPO activity crashed in 2008 when the economy fell into recession. The privatisation of Royal Mail, which has netted investors gains of more than 50% and complaints that it was sold off too cheaply, has been the most high-profile share offer. But scores of other companies have come to market, raising a total of £10.6bn so far this year – the highest since a record £16.5bn in 2007, according to Dealogic. The roll-call of firms going public includes housebuilder Crest Nicholson, whose shares have gained 70% on the back of surging house prices in London and the south-east, and estate agency Foxtons, which has gained 30% since its flotation last month. Life insurance company Partnership Assurance has also seen a rising share price, although insurer esure bucked the trend, with its shares sliding since its listing in March. In the waiting room for market listings are sofa retailer DFS, over-50s women's fashion retailer Bonmarché and property website Zoopla. Katya Kuznetsova, director of capital markets at PricewaterhouseCoopers, said IPO activity had picked up at the end of the summer as private equity investors sought to take advantage of favourable market conditions and sell stakes. "Private equity [investors] had been sitting on their portfolios for a long time and they were desperate to exit." According to PWC's analysis, four of the five biggest IPOs in London have seen their stock price rise faster than the FTSE 100 average for blue chip companies. Kuznetsova predicted that "strong" IPO activity would continue well into next year. With a valuation of £3bn, Merlin ould sail into the FTSE 100 when it makes its stock market debut next month. The company plans to use the proceeds of the sale to pay off £200m worth of debt, as well as opening more theme parks and waxwork museums in Asia and north America. In 2014 the company will open a huge Madame Tussauds near Tiananmen Square in Beijing. Also to be unveiled next year in the US are a Madame Tussauds and a "dungeon" for San Francisco, a Sealife Centre in Charlotte, North Carolina and a small indoor Legoland "discovery centre" in Boston. In 2011 Merlin opened Legoland in Florida, stepping onto the turf of its number one rival Disney. Varney said public ownership would help to fund such long-term projects. "Private equity has been good, but being bought and sold every three to five years can be disruptive. We also need to be able to consider some long-term investment projects that under private equity ownership you wouldn't be able to do because of their investment horizons." The company's 22,000 employees will be offered shares at discounted rates, while members of the public buying Merlin shares will be entitled to a 30% discount on theme parks. Such offers have been dismissed as gimmicks by analysts – Merlin is offering a 25% discount to people booking tickets on its website, while the remaining saving would be swallowed up in fees. The recession does not appear to have put customers off visiting Legoland or the waxworks museum. The total number of visitors to Merlin's theme parks has been growing by around 11% a year since 2008, with the fastest growth coming from Asia.

webTitle: Tapering growth in home lending keeps Australian interest rates steady

fields.standfirst: August figures show growth in housing loans has eased for the fifth month in a row, halting housing bubble speculation
fields.body:
The housing finance data released last week by the ABS put a bit of a halt on the housing price bubble story, and also a halt on any changes to interests rates in the short term.

After a few weeks of seemingly incessant noise about the booming housing market, the August figures showed the growth in housing loans eased for the fifth month in a row, with the value of loans in August growing by only 0.5%, down from 1.8% in March.

So while the housing market continues to improve, the heat does seem to have come out of it somewhat. It could be that the September election influenced sales, however it looks more like just a continuation of a trend.

Certainly housing prices have increased. As the RBA noted in the minutes of its latest board meeting, house prices increased by around 2.5% over the September quarter and by 5.5% over the year. But we need a bit of perspective. As I’ve noted a few times, the “boom” in prices is not in the same league as occurred in the early 2000s after the RBA cut interest rates by two percentage points after January 2001.

Back then, 21 months after the cycle of lowering rates occurred, the average housing loan for owner occupiers was 35% higher than it was in February 2001. By comparison 21 months since November 2011 when the RBA began cutting rates to the tune of 2.25 percentage points, the average home loan is now only 11% higher than it was 21 months ago.

So the boom continues to be more in sales than in prices:

The focus of the story thus shifted to the decline in first-home buyers because the percentage of housing loans going to first home buyers had fallen to its lowest level since 2004:

But while the decline in the past 12 months is significant, for the most part, since the end of the housing boom in 2004, first-home buyers have only accounted for more than 20% of home loans during the GFC when the first-homer buyer’s grant was doubled (and tripled for new homes). Back during the 1990s when first-home buyers comprised around 22% of home loans, the price of a house was on average around four times the average household’s annual income. By 2004 it was around seven times — and nearly eight times in the capital cities.

So the question of whether first home buyers have been priced out of the market was answered 10 years ago.

What has changed recently however for first-home buyers, as noted by Amanda Lynch in Business Spectator, is the first-home owner grants (FHOG). In New South Wales for example, the FHOG for established homes ceased in September 2012; in Victoria it finished in June this year. In those states, as well as Queensland and the ACT, first home buyers can only get the grant if they a build or buy a new home.

This policy shift is certainly welcome, as the FOHG for established homes did little other than add a dose of spice to the demand side of the market. The introduction in 2000 of the grants spurred investment more than it did owner occupiers. The numbers of first-home buyers actually fell from the end of 2001 to 2004, while the value of loans for first-home buyers soared around 30% during that period.

The Reserve Bank, however is more concerned with price rises generally rather than just for first-home buyers, and also with the impact of monetary policy on spurring construction and investment in the housing market.

Given the recent discussion by the Reserve Bank of self-managed superannuation funds in the housing market, it’s not surprising to discover than in the past 24 months housing finance for investors has exceeded that for owner occupiers. But it remains well below boom levels:

So while investors certainly are bolstering the market, it is not such that owner occupiers are being squeezed out — indeed 64% of all housing loans are for owner occupiers — a level that has been quite constant for the past decade.

But while buying and selling and renting out established homes might help generate “wealth” (or at least the illusion of it), the general economy benefits more from the construction of new homes. Thus far the growth in loans for established houses is exceeding that of construction. Annual growth to August in the number of loans for construction of new housing grew by 6.4% compared to 12% for established homes.

This accords with the most recent building activity data which showed construction of residential building activity remains positive, if not spectacular:

Thus far the RBA’s monetary policy change since November 2011 has clearly had an impact, but it remains a steady as she goes impact. And given that, I expect the RBA will continue for some while to keep interest rates steady as well.
